abstract.p: Various energy harvesting systems have been proposed in the last years. The use of ambient energy, such as vibration energy, has evoked great interests. Most vibration-based converters generate the maximum power only when the generator is excited at its resonance frequency. To overcome this limitation, researchers focus on strategies for increasing the working bandwidth of an energy harvester. Due to the amount of different approaches for broadband energy harvesting, we suggest a categorization. This review presents a classification of the current techniques. Every technique has its own benefits and drawbacks and is suitable for different applications. This review presents the categorization and describes each conversion technique. Typical research approaches are shown to get a better understanding of the energy harvesting techniques. The advantages and drawbacks are presented, and the suitability is shown for each category.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the last years, the field of energy harvesting has become a promising technique as power supply of autonomous electronic devices. These devices use the surrounding energy, such as vibrations, temperature gradients, or radiation, for conversion into electrical energy. Mechanical vibrations are an attractive source due to their high availability in technical environments; thus, numerous research groups are working on this topic. The most important conversion methods for ambient vibrations are electromagnetic, electrostatic, and piezoelectric. All these techniques have been successfully demonstrated in the past. Priya and Inman (2009) provide an overview of the basics in energy harvesting. Their book presents different conversion methods and gives an analytical analysis of the theory. In addition, the volume shows some state-of-the-art applications for energy harvesting.

The major drawback is that the energy harvester generates the most energy when the generator is excited at its resonance frequency. Hence, the converter needs to be tuned to the main external frequency of the individual environment. If the excitation frequency shifts, the performance of the generator is drastically reduced. In practical use, the vibration of an environment may vary in a large spectrum. To overcome this disadvantage, researchers work hard to increase the working bandwidth of an energy harvester.

This review presents a classification of the current techniques for broadband vibration energy harvesters. Due to the amount of different approaches to widen the operating frequency range, we suggest a categorization in Figure 1. Every technique has its own benefits and drawbacks. A classification shows the suitability of the energy harvesting device for their application. The methods are divided into groups of different conversion techniques. Each technique is described, and the advantages and disadvantages are summarized. A detailed analysis is given, and every technique is explained with an example of a current research study. All conversion methods are presented in the following sections. In this context, the authors decide for typical approaches representing the methods in Figure 1. Section “Classification of broadband techniques for vibration energy harvesting” gives the classification of broadband techniques for vibration energy harvesting. Section “Examples for broadband techniques” shows examples for broadband techniques. Section “Conclusion” evaluates the suitability of the different conversion methods. The advantages and disadvantages between all approaches are described, and a table shows the suitability for certain circumstances.

sec.title: Classification of broadband techniques for vibration energy harvesting
sec.p: Broadband energy harvesting can be divided into three different groups. The first one is the use of linear generators. This is characterized by a geometric arrangement of single converters. Linear generators are energy harvesters with a behavior nearly like a linear system. The second group contains the nonlinear generators. In this case, the nonlinear effects are essential to increase the operating bandwidth. The third set is advanced electronic network circuits. Thereby, the electrical load is modified to increase the performance. All groups have additionally subgroups given in Figure 1 and described in the following.
We divide the current strategies for broadband energy harvesting into three different methods:

sec.title: Linear generators
sec.p: Linear generators may be modeled as single-degree-of-freedom (SDOF) systems. The equation of motion for this fundamental modeling is given by Williams and Yates (1996) for a general vibration energy harvesting system

list-item.p: Piezoelectric conversion. The piezoelectric material transforms the strain in the mechanical system into electrical energy.
Electromagnetic conversion. The mechanical energy is transformed into electrical energy using a magnet moving relative to a coil.
Electrostatic conversion. The plates of a plate capacitive transducer oscillate and induce a voltage on the plates.

sec.title: Generator arrays
sec.p: Linear generators are most efficient if the excitation frequency equates the resonance frequency of the energy harvester. One solution to increase the bandwidth is the use of multiple cantilevers or an cantilever array. Figure 2 shows a principle generator array. Figure 2(a) gives a schematic overview about a typical generator array, and Figure 2(b) shows the transfer function corresponding to the beam–mass systems of the device. Every single converter beam shows linear behavior. The single cantilevers are tuned in a way that all resonance frequencies are comparable close to each other. The beams are mounted on the vibration source. The resonance frequencies are adjusted by tuning the geometry of each energy scavenger or by applying a proof mass. As long as the source vibration has dominant frequency within the band of the array, at least one of the beams operates at its resonance frequency. Hence, as more beams are added to the array, as much bigger is the possible bandwidth. To get the highest possible output, the single generators should not be directly connected electrically due to the interdependence between them. This affects the possible performance. However, in most cases, an electrical serial or parallel connection is used, in order to simplify the setup.

caption.p: (a) Schematic view of the generator arry and (b) Transfer functions of the single generators.

sec.p: The main advantage of this broadband technique is that the setup is variable. It is easy to add or remove a single cantilever and to adjust their resonance frequencies. Furthermore, the array is not sensitive to mechanical disturbances of the excitation with impacts or short interrupts.

The disadvantage is that the setup requires a bulky volume. That could be a drawback for small-scale devices. A second handicap is the electronic network to manage the power output. For example, one can use rectifier bridges for each single beam and switches in the circuit, which will increase the cost of the device.

sec.title: Combined eigenmodes
sec.p: Another method is using more complex structures with two or more resonance frequencies that are very close to each other. Again, cantilever structures might be used, and these are connected in certain manners. Possible solutions are direct-connected beams or the coupling of multiple beams with springs. Figure 3 gives a schematic configuration of two coupled cantilevers. Figure 3(a) shows the design of the energy harvester. Figure 3(b) gives the corresponding transfer function. Usually, the first two eigenmodes of single cantilevers have a rather big frequency difference. The combination of two or more generators can shift those first eigenmodes closer to each other. The two-mass system has a higher bandwidth for a certain output level.

caption.p: (a) Schematic view of the coupled generators and (b) Transfer functions oft the coupled generators.

sec.p: The advantages of this setup are that the system is comparatively compact and robust against external influences. This generator is not sensitive to disturbances.

The disadvantage within the combined eigenmodes is the reduction of the response in each individual mode due to the mode coupling. A vibration absorber can reduce the amplitude in a specific frequency range of the basic mass due to a second mass that is mechanically coupled to the system. The optimized damping can achieve a broadband response.

sec.title: Nonlinear generators
sec.p: The utilization of nonlinear effects can improve the energy generation and the bandwidth of energy harvesters. We identify the following three different generic types of nonlinear generators:

sec.title: Bistable/multistable generators
sec.p: A bistable or multistable generator is an energy harvester with more than one stable equilibrium position. Such a system can be modeled with a nonlinear stiffness. Ramlan et al. (2009) describe a general nonlinear energy scavenger as an SDOF system with the equation of motion

caption.p: (a) Schematic view of the bistable system and (b) Potential energy of the system.

sec.p: Multistable generators exhibit even more equilibrium positions. In these generators, the system jumps from one equilibrium to another and settles at its natural frequency. Due to the ambient excitation, the system jumps back and forth between the equilibrium positions. The free settling oscillation at resonance gives the extra power because the amplitude is much higher compared to the amplitude that would be exhibited due to the low excitation frequency in one equilibrium position.
Bistable/multistable generators show a good performance especially for small frequencies and have a large operating frequency range with a small size of the device.

The disadvantage is that the converter typically needs an auxiliary structure to design the nonlinear stiffness. Another problem is the necessity of an accurate design in terms of low tolerances to achieve a broadband energy scavenger.

sec.title: Amplitude limiter
sec.p:
Another method to widen the bandwidth is through the use of the amplitude limiter. These devices use a mechanical stopper to limit the amplitude of the vibrations and are often called vibroimpact systems. The theory is rather complex, and as an example, Soliman et al. (2008) give an analysis of the system behavior. Figure 5 shows a schematic view of an amplitude-limiting system. The mass
m
is oscillating between two mechanical stoppers; consequently, the maximum amplitude is
Δ
. The generator can be modeled as a SDOF system with a damping coefficient
d
and a stiffness
c
. Figure 5(b) gives the frequency response of the model. For small amplitudes, the system behaves like a linear system. At a certain frequency and certain exciting amplitude, the mass hits the stopper. As soon as this level is reached, the frequency response remains on this plateau even with increasing frequencies. Here, a new stable region is added to the frequency spectrum. Only as long as no or minor disturbances occur, the system stays in this new region; otherwise, the response will drop on the linear behavior. Reaching this new region is only possible close to the resonance frequency of the linear system because the initial high amplitude is necessary.

caption.p: (a) Schematic view of the amplitude-limiting system and (b) Frequency response function.

sec.p: The advantages are the robust and compact setup. Furthermore, the converter is theoretically always on the plateau with a huge bandwidth. But to reach the new stable path, a complex driving strategy is necessary, which is not possible in all cases. A slowly increasing frequency sweep is necessary to stay on the high plateau. The energy scavenger is also very sensitive to disturbances that make the system jump to the low-level plateau in Figure 5(b).

sec.title: Active resonance tuning
sec.p:
Another possibility to achieve broadband energy harvesting is an active resonance tuning. As described in section “Introduction,” in real applications, the excitation frequency is neither constant nor known. Therefore, a tuning of the harvester frequency is useful. Now, it is the idea to change this harvester property during the run time of the energy scavenger to match the excitation frequency. Figure 6(a) shows a fundamental electrical equivalent circuit representation of an energy harvesting system with an electrical load. The picture symbolizes the mechanical tunability of the resonance frequency: For adjustment of the resonance frequency, the mass
m
or the stiffness
c
m
may be adopted. A further possibility is the adjustment of the electrical components to tune the resonance frequency. Figure 6(b) shows different power spectra for various resonance frequencies and the range for the operating frequency due to a variation of
m
. Two tuning techniques are common: first, the continuous tuning mechanism. Here, the parameters of the generator are tuned continuously to match the excitation frequency. Therefore, the tuning system has to be powered all the time and will consume a high percentage of the harvested energy. The second approach is an intermittent tuning approach. Here, the system is either time controlled every couple of minutes or the exciting frequency is monitored and the tuning is activated at a certain threshold. The intermittent tuning is preferable for systems with slow or seldom shifts in the excitation frequencies.

caption.p: (a) Schematic view of the active resonance tuning system and (b) Power spectra for different resonance frequencies.

sec.p: The active resonance tuning technique provides that the generator always operates at resonance frequency with a high power output.

The disadvantage of this technique is the power supply for the active tuning. A second drawback is the need for a rather complex auxiliary structure to adopt the generators’ mass and stiffness parameters.

sec.title: Advanced electronic networks
sec.p:
In addition to the linear and nonlinear techniques for broadband energy harvesting by changing the properties of the converter, a smart electrical network can increase the bandwidth significantly. However, the focus of this review is on mechanical techniques for broadband energy harvesting but for the sake of completeness, advanced electronic networks can improve the power generation. Besides many others, a very promising approach is that proposed by Badel et al. (2005). This technique is called synchronous switch harvesting on inductor (SSHI). The SSHI branch is connected in parallel with the piezoelectric element, as shown in Figure 7. This branch consists of a switch and an inductor

sec.title: Examples for broadband techniques
sec.p: Section “Classification of broadband techniques for vibration energy harvesting” already presents the idea of different broadband techniques. This section gives some examples from recent research projects to the presented methods.

sec.title: Generator arrays
sec.p: In addition, section “Generator arrays” consists of multiple linear converters and Figure 8 shows some examples. Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the power generator presented by Liu et al. (2008). Figure 8(a) gives the microelectromechanical system (MEMS) based on thick-film piezoelectric cantilevers. The array is excited by a vibration source with an acceleration of 0.5g. Three cantilevers (C1–C3) are connected as an array. The beams have resonance frequencies of 226, 229, and 234 Hz that are adjusted with different tip masses. The bandwidth of this configuration is 226–234 Hz with a higher output voltage after rectification. Figure 8(b) shows the array excited with a frequency of 229 Hz and the alternating current (AC) voltage of each cantilever. For a serial connection, the output power is 3.98 µW.

caption.p: Examples of generator arrays by Liu et al. (2008) and Xue et al. (2008): (a and b) experimental setup simulated power output of the generator array by Liu et al. (2008) and (c and d) model and voltage output of the generator array by Xue et al. (2008).
PCB: printed circuit board; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: Xue et al. (2008) give a further example for an array structure, as shown in Figure 8. This setup is analyzed by numerical simulations. The array consists of multiple piezoelectric cantilevers with different thicknesses to adjust the resonance frequencies. The generated power is measured across a load resistor. Figure 8(c) presents the piezoelectric harvester. Figure 8(d) gives the corresponding power spectrum for a serial connection of 10 bimorphs. The frequency band with an output power higher than 10 µW has widened from 97–103 Hz to 87–115 Hz.

Shahruz (2006) presents a theoretical study of piezoelectric generator array that consists of an ensemble of cantilevers with tip masses. The beams are modeled as generalized SDOF system. By designing the dimensions of the beams and the proof masses, the bandwidth of the generator array can be adapted. A single generator is excited in its resonance frequency in a specific frequency range.

sec.title: Combined eigenmodes
sec.p: Combined eigenmode generators have a larger bandwidth if some resonance frequencies are close enough to each other. Figure 9 shows two examples of combined eigenmodes. Yang and Yang (2009) propose a theoretical analysis of connected or coupled bimorph beams. Figure 9(a) is the model that is used for the analyses. The system consists of two cantilevers, and the end masses are elastically connected with a linear stiffness. The power density, defined as the output power per unit volume, is shown in Figure 9(b) for three cases of different end mass ratios. Typically, there are two peaks, and the distance relates to the mass ratio. The peaks can be shifted to get a wideband output for a minimum output power.

caption.p: Examples of combined eigenmodes: (a and b) model and power output of the energy harvester by Yang and Yang (2009) and (c and d) model and power output of the converter by Erturk et al. (2009b).

sec.p: A further approach is that proposed by Erturk et al. (2009b). The energy harvesting system is called a L-shaped piezoelectric harvester. Three bimorphs are firmly connected and mounted to the (ambient) vibration source. A schematic view of the converter is given in Figure 9(c). In the cited study, the energy scavenger is studied theoretically. The frequency response functions (FRFs) are given in Figure 9(d). It can be realized that the first two resonance frequencies of the first and second modes are relatively close to each other. The cancellations in mode 1 or 2 due to the electrical connection are not described in this article. The FRF shows the wideband response of the generator.

Petropoulos et al. (2004) use a MEMS structure for electromagnetic energy harvesting. The system consists of magnet masses, moving in relation to coils. The coupled oscillator uses multiple masses and springs, and it is shown that a change of the parameters can achieve a wide variety of spectral behavior.

sec.title: Bistable/multistable generators
sec.p: Bistable/multistable generators are described in section “Bistable/multistable generators” and exhibit two or more equilibrium positions. Figure 10 presents examples of current approaches. Figure 10(a) and (b) shows the nonlinear piezoelectric energy harvester by Stanton et al. (2009). This converter is modeled and experimentally validated. The system consists of a piezoelectric bimorph with a magnetic end mass (Figure 10(a)). Two other magnets are oppositely poled and located near the tip magnet. The magnets have a repulsive force against each other. The system may be modeled with the mechanical Duffing equations

caption.p: Examples of bistable/multistable generators: (a and b) experimental setup and power output by Stanton et al. (2009), (c and d) experimental setup and voltage output by Sneller et al. (2011), and (e and f) model setup and tip displacement by Wickenheiser and Garcia (2010).

sec.p: A second example is given in Figure 10(c) and (d) by Sneller et al. (2011). Figure 10(c) shows the experimental setup of a postbuckled piezoelectric beam with an attached central mass. The forced buckled structure is subject to harmonic vibrations and exhibits snap-through behavior. The system has two stable equilibrium positions, and the system vibrates from one stable equilibrium to another. A theoretical model describes the behavior of the beam that is dependent to the central mass and the preload. Figure 10(d) presents the broadband voltage output for a frequency sweep.

A multistable system is given in Figure 10(e) and (f) by Wickenheiser and Garcia (2010). Figure 10(e) shows a schematic view of the system. The energy harvester consists of a piezoelectric bimorph with a magnetic end mass. A ferromagnetic passive structure is placed near the magnet. The auxiliary structure becomes magnetized by the tip magnet. The generator has multistable equilibrium positions due to the attracting positions of the tip magnet to the auxiliary structure. Figure 10(f) presents the base and tip displacements for a low-frequency excitation for different distances to the passive structure. The system excitation leads the beam into an equilibrium position, and the cantilever oscillates at its resonance frequency. The excitation guides the converter into the next equilibrium. Especially for low frequencies, the system generates more energy due to its free vibrations.

Erturk et al. (2009a) present a piezomagnetoelastic energy harvesting device. The generator consists of a firmly clamped ferroelectric beam and two permanent magnets located near the free end of the cantilever. The system is subject to harmonic oscillations with three equilibrium positions (with two stable) and can be described with the Duffing equation.

sec.title: Amplitude limiter
sec.p: Amplitude limiter or vibroimpact systems are presented in section “Bistable/multistable generators.” Two examples are shown in Figure 11. Figure 11(a) and (b) describes the experimental study by Blystad and Halvorsen (2011). The transducer is a piezoelectric bimorph with end mass, and it is firmly attached to the host structure. A mechanical end stop is implemented on one side. This metal plate limits the movement for large amplitudes. Figure 11(b) shows a voltage frequency sweep. For the sweep-up, the voltage output increases until the bimorph comes into contact with the stopper. The response continues with the expected plateau, and at a certain frequency, the system jumps back to the linear output.

caption.p: Amplitude limiting by Blystad and Halvorsen (2011) and Moss et al. (2010): (a and b) experimental setup and voltage output of the energy scavenger by Blystad and Halvorsen (2011) and (c and d) model and peak displacement of the vibroimpact system by Moss et al. (2010).

sec.p: A second research project has been done by Moss et al. (2010). Figure 11(c) gives a schematic view of the vibroimpact energy harvester. The converter consists of a passive main cantilever with a seismic mass. Furthermore, two bimorphs are used as stopper. The seismic mass hits the bimorphs with certain amplitude. Figure 11(d) shows the peak displacement of the passive cantilever and the bimorphs. The broadband response with a plateau can be recognized in the frequency response.

Another approach is presented by Galchev et al. (2011). The transducer is an electromagnetic energy scavenger. The system consists of three magnetically coupled mechanical structures. Two springs are placed on each side of a movable mass. A magnet for power generation is attached at the bottom of the springs, and on the top of the springs, there is a second magnet to generate a magnetic field that is used to attract the initial mass. The combination of a vibroimpact contact and the magnetic force of attraction realizes the amplitude limiter. Furthermore, Galchev et al. (2011) suggest comparison between different vibration energy harvesting systems based on the volume figure of merit by Mitcheson et al. (2008).

sec.title: Active resonance tuning
sec.p: Section “Active resonance tuning” describes the principle of active resonance tuning methods. Figure 12 presents two experimental validated active resonance tuning approaches. The experimental setup by Challa et al. (2008) is given in Figure 12(a). The energy harvester is a piezoelectric cantilever with an end mass. Four permanent magnets are used in this setup. Two are attached at the tip mass, and two more are fixed to the host structure at the top and bottom of the device. On one side of the beam, the magnets attract each other and they have a repulsive force on the other side. By adjusting the distances between the magnets, the resonance frequency is shifted. Figure 12(b) shows the power outputs for different magnet distances. The generator with a resonance frequency of 26 Hz is tuned over a frequency range of 22–32 Hz. In this case, the magnetic force is used to alter the overall stiffness of the system.

caption.p: Active resonance tuning by Challa et al. (2008) and Leland and Wright (2006): (a and b) experimental setup and range of resonance frequency tunability by Challa et al. (2008) and (c and d) model and peak displacement of the vibroimpact system by Leland and Wright (2006).

sec.p: Another approach is that presented by Leland and Wright (2006). Figure 12(c) depicts the experimental configuration. The transducer is a piezoelectric bimorph with central proof mass. A small steel vise was custom-machined to hold the bimorph and facilitate the application of compressive axial preload. A vise is used therefore as well as to mount the beam. The compressive axial preload reduces the transverse stiffness, which also reduces the resonance frequency. Figure 12(d) shows the results of a preload change on the resonance frequency, and it can be reduced from 250 to 200 Hz. The bimorph strength is too low for higher loads. However, the output power remains approximately constant between 300 and 400 µW with increasing preload.

Another example is that given by Mann and Sims (2009). The system is an electromagnetic energy scavenger that uses magnetic levitation to achieve a generator with a tunable resonance frequency. A free center magnet is placed between two fixed outer magnets. By adjusting the magnet spacing, the resonance frequency can be shifted. The Duffing equation describes the system dynamics.

sec.p: Table 1 summarizes the presented broadband techniques and their suitability. The group of linear generators is more efficient for stochastic excitations with a variable setup. The output power compared to the size of the device is much worse than for nonlinear generators. Nonlinear energy harvesting systems are not only more efficient but also more sensitive to disturbances. Nonlinear techniques are very suitable for wideband approximately harmonic excitations or a very low-frequency excitations. All the presented methods are suitable for their specific applications, but none of them can be called a universal solution.
